ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: senior thesis prep
Learned a lot about how to narrow down a specific topic of interest; learned how to evaluate secondary sources and use those to tell your own story.

I had the chance to dive deep into both archival and secondary source research. I learned so much about my thesis topic, including what others have written about it, and corresponded with many people in the field. The thesis class gave me time and space to fully immerse myself in historical research, which was awesome.
I improved my research skills!
Thesis is fun! Do a two-semester one, it's worth it.
Primary historical research.

Skills in research, such as finding sources, processing information, and analysis. Also, putting multiple pieces of work in conversation with each other. And plenty of knowledge on the Roman imperial cult

I learned how to use the Yale archives, and dive deeper into a topic that I would not otherwise know much about. I also think writing a senior essay shows future employers/grad schools that you are capable of committing to a year long project and have some evidence of your reading and writing skills.

I gained a lot of insight into writing a full-length historical article through this course. The course assignments helped me stay on track and plan my thesis process in detail for the rest of the year, and they forced me to learn a lot about my research and writing styles. I look forward to building upon this work throughout the spring semester as I finish my history thesis.
I learned how to commit to a much deeper level of research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: all strengths

The assignments could be structured better to work towards the 10 page draft due at the end of the semester. More emphasis should be placed around finding an engaging primary source early-on rather than digging into secondary sources because ultimately they might not be relevant to the primary sources available.

The set of assignments in the first semester of the thesis is hefty and requires students to define their topics quite quickly. I think that is good, but could have been made clearer from the outside. In addition, it was unclear until around mid-semester how we were supposed to submit our work in order to make sure that our completion of assignments was documented.

A little more guidance on the History Funding would have been cool! I didn't know I was supposed to submit certain materials, and it was overall a messy process for me. Otherwise, love the history department!
just gotta do it
Good opportunity to advance research skills.

This course is hard to evaluate because it is so personal to each student, but I think the senior essay could be improved by having a weekly or biweekly meeting expectation set. I met with my advisor every two or three weeks at my request, but there was no expectation that we meet that often/I have peers writing a senior essay who hardly know their advisor.

The strengths of this course were my history advisor and the class' required assignments, which kept me on track throughout the semester. However, the weakness of this course was its organization. Although I know it would be hard to organize, I think the history senior thesis could be much more effective if the class met in person rather than asynchronously. The department often did not send reminders or further information about upcoming assignments, sometimes leaving my peers and me to scramble. I also wish that the department could provide more information about historical and research methods to help us improve our technique as undergraduates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes
Yes, writing a thesis is super fulfilling especially when you have an advisor who is super knowledgable and really cares about you!

I would recommend that History majors do the two-semester thesis and ensure they have time to dedicate to it both semesters. It has been a very valuable capstone to the History major so far, and it's nice to feel like I'm doing a project I can really be proud of.
Sure! I mean, it's a requirement, so to an extent I would "recommend" it, but it was a wonderful course! I felt very supported by my thesis advisor and by Professor Fancy, as well as by Essie!
you have no choice
yes. It is a great challenge.
Yes, I think that a two-term senior essay should be a requirement of all history majors that are not double majoring.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. I have had a fantastic time as a history major, and I think the thesis is a unique and meaningful process that every student should experience during their time at Yale. Moreover, I have learned so much from my thesis advisor, granting me in-depth one-on-one feedback unlike any other history course I have taken as an undergraduate.
It is really nice to spend a lot of time really committing to in one subject of research
